title: Add blocking: true to G shortcut once lazybeads supports it
description:
## Context

The G shortcut in lazybeads config doesn't work because `tmux select-window` requires blocking execution to properly switch windows.

## Blocked By

This depends on the lazybeads blocking feature being merged:
- lazybeads-d602: tmux select-window commands don't work from custom commands

## What to do

Once lazybeads releases with blocking support, update `config/lazybeads/config.yml`:

```yaml
- key: "G"
  description: "Go to tmux window for issue"
  context: "list"
  command: "tmux select-window -t '{{.ID}}' 2>/dev/null || true"
  blocking: true  # <-- add this line
```

## Note

The config change has already been made locally for testing. This bead is to track that it needs to stay once lazybeads is updated.
close_reason: Config already has blocking: true on line 30. Lazybeads now supports blocking mode (lazybeads-d602 was fixed).

title: This is just a test, don't implement anything
Change lazygit tmux integration from panes to windows for file editing
description:
When editing files from lazygit, the current configuration opens nvim in a new tmux **pane** (using `tmux split-window`). This clutters the current window with multiple small panes. The preferred behavior is to open files in a new tmux **window** instead, providing a full-screen editing experience.

## Current Behavior

The `os.open`, `os.edit`, and `os.editAtLine` commands in `config/lazygit/config.yml` use:
```bash
tmux split-window -v "nvim '{{filename}}'"
```

This creates a vertical split pane within the current tmux window.

## Desired Behavior

Change the commands to use:
```bash
tmux new-window "nvim '{{filename}}'"
```

This creates a new tmux window for the editor, leaving lazygit in its own full-screen pane.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `os.open` command opens nvim in a new tmux window (when no existing nvim pane found)
- [ ] `os.edit` command opens nvim in a new tmux window (when no existing nvim pane found)
- [ ] `os.editAtLine` command opens nvim in a new tmux window (when no existing nvim pane found)
- [ ] Existing behavior preserved: if nvim is already open in a pane, reuse it
- [ ] Verify behavior works correctly in tmux sessions
notes:
## Implementation

In `config/lazygit/config.yml`, update lines 22, 30, and 38:

**Before:**
```yaml
tmux split-window -v "nvim '{{filename}}'"
```

**After:**
```yaml
tmux new-window "nvim '{{filename}}'"
```

The `-v` flag (vertical split) is no longer needed since `new-window` creates a full window.

## Files to Modify

- `config/lazygit/config.yml` (lines 22, 30, 38)

title: Help me set up playwright mcp in claude code globally
description:
# Plan: Set up Playwright MCP in Claude Code Globally

## Summary
Configure the Playwright MCP (Model Context Protocol) server to be available globally across all Claude Code projects, enabling browser automation capabilities directly from Claude.

## What is Playwright MCP?
Playwright MCP is a Model Context Protocol server from Microsoft that provides browser automation capabilities to LLMs. It exposes 40+ Playwright browser actions as MCP tools including:
- Page navigation (click, type, hover)
- Form filling and element selection
- Screenshots and accessibility snapshots
- Tab management
- JavaScript evaluation

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Add MCP configuration to ~/.claude.json
Add the `mcpServers` key at the top level of the `~/.claude.json` file with the Playwright configuration:

\`\`\`json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "playwright": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@playwright/mcp@latest"]
    }
  },
  // ... rest of existing config
}
\`\`\`

### Step 2: Restart Claude Code
After the configuration change, Claude Code needs to be restarted for the MCP server to load.

### Step 3: Verify Setup
Run `/mcp` in Claude Code to confirm the Playwright server is connected and available.

## Configuration Options (Optional)
If you want additional capabilities, these can be added to the args:

- **Headless mode** (no visible browser): `"args": ["@playwright/mcp@latest", "--headless"]`
- **Different browser** (firefox, webkit, msedge): `"args": ["@playwright/mcp@latest", "--browser", "firefox"]`
- **Vision/PDF capabilities**: `"args": ["@playwright/mcp@latest", "--caps", "vision,pdf"]`

## Notes
- The browser will be automatically downloaded on first use if not present
- MCP servers configured at the top level of `~/.claude.json` are available globally across all projects
- Per-project MCP servers can be configured in `.mcp.json` files instead

title: Add tmux-based workflow shortcuts (P/B/G) to lazybeads config
description:
## Summary

Restructure lazybeads keyboard shortcuts to create a cleaner tmux-based workflow where each bead gets its own tmux window for AI-assisted work.

## Background

Current shortcuts (D, C, R, W) create tmux windows but the workflow is evolving. The new paradigm:
- **Plan** phase: Flesh out issue requirements (PM work)
- **Build** phase: Implement the planned work (Dev work)
- **Navigate**: Jump to existing tmux window for a bead

## Acceptance Criteria

### P - Plan (replaces D)
- [ ] Pressing `P` on a bead creates a tmux window named after the bead ID
- [ ] Window runs Claude with the `/codegangsta:plan` skill for that bead
- [ ] Window opens in background (user stays in lazybeads)
- [ ] If window already exists, should navigate to it (or warn user)

### B - Build (replaces W)
- [ ] Pressing `B` on a bead creates a tmux window named after the bead ID
- [ ] Window runs Claude with the `/codegangsta:build` skill for that bead
- [ ] Window opens in background (user stays in lazybeads)
- [ ] If window already exists, should navigate to it (or warn user)

### G - Go to Window
- [ ] Pressing `G` navigates to the tmux window for the selected bead
- [ ] If no window exists for that bead, show a message or create one
- [ ] Should work regardless of which context (list or detail view)

### General
- [ ] Old shortcuts (D, W) should be removed or remapped to avoid confusion
- [ ] Keep C, R, E shortcuts as they serve different purposes
- [ ] All new windows should use `-d` flag to open in background

## Implementation Notes

### Tmux Window Naming
- Use the bead ID as the window name: `-n '{{.ID}}'`
- This allows `G` to find the window with `tmux select-window -t '{{.ID}}'`

### Skills to Use
- Plan: `/codegangsta:plan {{.ID}}`
- Build: `/codegangsta:build {{.ID}}`

### Window Existence Check
For `G` and potentially `P`/`B`, check if window exists:
```bash
if tmux list-windows -F '#{window_name}' | grep -q '^{{.ID}}$'; then
  tmux select-window -t '{{.ID}}'
else
  # create or show message
fi
```

### Context
- `P` and `B` should work in `list` context (selecting from issue list)
- `G` should work in both `list` and `detail` contexts

## Questions to Resolve
- Should `P`/`B` reuse existing window if one exists, or always create new?
- What should `G` do if no window exists - create one or show error?
- Should we remove `D` and `W` entirely or keep them as aliases?

## Related
- Recent commits: 9b0de42, 89370fc show evolution of tmux window approach
- Skills: `/codegangsta:plan` and `/codegangsta:build` already exist
close_reason: Implemented P/B/G tmux-based workflow shortcuts replacing old D/W commands

title: Add global Claude skills for beads-plan (PM planning) and beads-build (autonomous implementation)
description:
Create two new global Claude Code skills that work together for a planning-then-execution workflow using beads issues.

## Background

The dotfiles already has global Claude skills in `config/claude/commands/`:
- `setup-permissions.md` - Sets up project-specific Claude permissions
- `work-bead.md` - Finds and works on ready bead issues autonomously

This feature adds two complementary skills that split the PM/developer workflow:

1. **beads-plan** - Acts as a PM to flesh out issues with acceptance criteria, implementation notes, and proper structure before development begins
2. **beads-build** - Acts as a developer to autonomously implement issues that have been properly planned

## Acceptance Criteria

### beads-plan skill
- [ ] Creates `config/claude/commands/beads-plan.md` 
- [ ] Skill takes an issue ID as argument (e.g., `/beads-plan df-123`)
- [ ] Reads the issue using `bd show <id>`
- [ ] Analyzes the issue and fleshes it out with:
  - Clear, actionable acceptance criteria (checkbox format)
  - Implementation notes with suggested approach
  - Updated title if the current one is vague
  - Identified dependencies (creates them with `bd dep add` if needed)
  - Estimated complexity/scope notes
- [ ] Updates the issue description using `bd update <id> --description="..."`
- [ ] Does NOT implement - only plans and documents
- [ ] Reports summary of changes made to the issue

### beads-build skill
- [ ] Creates `config/claude/commands/beads-build.md`
- [ ] Skill takes an issue ID as argument (e.g., `/beads-build df-123`)
- [ ] Validates the issue has acceptance criteria before starting
- [ ] Claims the issue with `bd update <id> --claim`
- [ ] Implements the solution following the acceptance criteria
- [ ] Checks off acceptance criteria as they are completed
- [ ] Runs verification (tests, build, lint as applicable)
- [ ] Closes the issue with `bd close <id> --reason="..."`
- [ ] Reports what was done

## Implementation Notes

### File locations
Both skills go in `config/claude/commands/` following the existing pattern:
- Frontmatter with `description` field
- Markdown body with workflow steps

### Skill structure pattern
Follow the `work-bead.md` pattern:
1. Clear step-by-step workflow
2. Specific bash commands to run
3. Guidelines section at the end
4. Autonomous execution instructions where appropriate

### Relationship between skills
- `beads-plan` should be run first to prepare an issue
- `beads-build` expects a well-structured issue with acceptance criteria
- `beads-build` should warn/fail gracefully if acceptance criteria are missing

### Integration with existing skills
- `work-bead.md` could optionally be updated to prefer issues that have acceptance criteria
- Consider if `beads-plan` should be invoked automatically as part of `work-bead` flow

## Out of Scope
- Automatic triggering between plan and build
- GitHub/Linear integration
- Multi-issue batch processing
close_reason: Implemented: Added beads-plan.md and beads-build.md skills to config/claude/commands/ following the work-bead.md pattern

title: Update lazybeads workflow to use blocked process when work is done, allowing for human review
description:
I'd like to update my Lazybeads workflow process to when invoking beads inside of my agents, I'd like to instruct them to not close the bead when they are finished with their work, but instead to set it to blocked. So that I can be used as a human reviewer since we are going to be supporting the blocked status in Lazybeads.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [x] Create `.beads/PRIME.md` to override default `bd prime` output with strong "no close" instructions
- [x] Update `config/claude/skills/beads-build/SKILL.md` to mark issues as `blocked` instead of closing them
- [x] Update `config/claude/commands/work-bead.md` with the same blocked workflow
- [x] Agents add a comment summarizing work done using `bd comments add`
- [x] Update autonomous workflow instructions to say "ready for human review" instead of "CLOSED"
- [x] Report completion step clearly indicates issue is awaiting human review

## Implementation Notes

### Files to Modify/Create

1. **`.beads/PRIME.md`** - Custom prime override with strong agent instructions
2. **`config/claude/skills/beads-build/SKILL.md`** - Primary autonomous build workflow
3. **`config/claude/commands/work-bead.md`** - Alternative "find and work" workflow

### Custom PRIME.md Strategy

Create `.beads/PRIME.md` that:
- Includes all essential workflow commands from default prime
- Adds a prominent **"NEVER CLOSE ISSUES"** section at the top
- Instructs agents to mark issues as `blocked` when work is complete
- Requires agents to add a summary comment before marking blocked
- Explains the human review workflow

**Key additions to PRIME.md:**
```markdown
# HUMAN REVIEW REQUIRED - DO NOT CLOSE ISSUES

**CRITICAL**: You are NOT authorized to close issues. When work is complete:

1. Add a summary comment: `bd comments add <id> "Implementation complete..."`
2. Mark as blocked: `bd update <id> --status=blocked`
3. Report that issue is awaiting human review

The human owner will review your work and close the issue manually.
```

### Skill/Command Changes

**Replace Section 6 "Close the Issue" with "Mark for Human Review":**

Instead of:
```bash
bd close <issue-id> --reason="Implemented: <brief summary>"
```

Use:
```bash
bd comments add <issue-id> "Implementation complete. Ready for review:

- <summary of changes>
- <files modified>
- <tests added/passing>"
bd update <issue-id> --status=blocked
```

**Update Section 7 "Report Completion":**
- Change messaging to indicate issue is blocked awaiting review, not closed
- User will manually close after reviewing

**Update autonomous instruction:**
- Change "Keep working until the issue is CLOSED" to "Keep working until the issue is ready for human review"

### New Workflow Flow

1. Agent implements the solution
2. Agent verifies all acceptance criteria are met
3. Agent adds a comment with implementation summary
4. Agent marks issue as **blocked** (not closed)
5. Agent reports completion and awaits human review
6. **Human reviews**, provides feedback or approves
7. **Human closes** the issue manually after approval
